spaceObjects.name: Black Holes
spaceObjects.description: A black hole is a region of spacetime where gravity is so strong that nothing—no particles or even electromagnetic radiation such as light—can escape from it.
facts: Black holes form when massive stars die and collapse under their own gravity.
The boundary of a black hole is called the event horizon, beyond which nothing can escape.
Time slows down near a black hole due to gravitational time dilation.
Supermassive black holes exist at the center of most galaxies, including our Milky Way.
Black holes can grow by absorbing mass or merging with other black holes.
spaceObjects.discovery: First predicted by Einstein's theory of general relativity in 1916
spaceObjects.size: From a few kilometers (stellar) to billions of kilometers (supermassive)
spaceObjects.detection: Detected indirectly through their effects on surrounding matter and space
spaceObjects.famous: Sagittarius A* (center of Milky Way), M87* (first photographed black hole)

spaceObjects.name: Nebulae
spaceObjects.description: A nebula is an interstellar cloud of dust, hydrogen, helium and other ionized gases. Originally, the term was used to describe any diffuse astronomical object, including galaxies beyond the Milky Way.
facts: Nebulae are often star-forming regions, such as in the 'Pillars of Creation' in the Eagle Nebula.
Planetary nebulae form when a dying star expels its outer layers of gas.
Supernova remnants are nebulae created by the explosion of a star.
The Orion Nebula is one of the brightest nebulae and can be seen with the naked eye.
Some nebulae are illuminated by stars, while others block light and appear as dark patches.
spaceObjects.types: Emission, Reflection, Dark, Planetary, Supernova Remnants
spaceObjects.size: Can span hundreds of light-years across
spaceObjects.composition: Interstellar dust, hydrogen, helium, and other ionized gases
spaceObjects.famous: Orion Nebula, Eagle Nebula, Crab Nebula, Helix Nebula, Cat's Eye Nebula

spaceObjects.name: Galaxies
spaceObjects.description: A galaxy is a gravitationally bound system of stars, stellar remnants, interstellar gas, dust, and dark matter. The Milky Way is the galaxy that contains our Solar System.
facts: There are estimated to be over 100 billion galaxies in the observable universe.
Galaxies come in various shapes and sizes, including spiral, elliptical, and irregular.
The Milky Way is a barred spiral galaxy containing 100-400 billion stars.
Galaxies are often found in groups or clusters, bound together by gravity.
The Andromeda Galaxy is on a collision course with the Milky Way, expected to merge in about 4.5 billion years.
spaceObjects.size: From a few thousand to hundreds of thousands of light-years across
spaceObjects.famous: Milky Way, Andromeda Galaxy, Whirlpool Galaxy, Sombrero Galaxy

spaceObjects.name: Stars
spaceObjects.description: A star is an astronomical object consisting of a luminous spheroid of plasma held together by its own gravity. The nearest star to Earth is the Sun.
facts: Stars are born in nebulae from collapsing clouds of gas and dust.
Stars generate energy through nuclear fusion, primarily converting hydrogen to helium.
The color of a star depends on its surface temperature, with blue stars being the hottest and red stars the coolest.
Stars have different sizes, from neutron stars (about 20 km in diameter) to supergiants (over 1,500 times the Sun's diameter).
When massive stars die, they can explode as supernovae, leaving behind neutron stars or black holes.
spaceObjects.types: Main Sequence, Giants, Supergiants, White Dwarfs, Neutron Stars
spaceObjects.lifecycle: Nebula → Protostar → Main Sequence → Red Giant/Supergiant → White Dwarf/Supernova → Neutron Star/Black Hole
spaceObjects.composition: Primarily hydrogen and helium, with trace amounts of heavier elements
spaceObjects.famous: Sun, Sirius, Betelgeuse, Proxima Centauri, UY Scuti (largest known star)

spaceObjects.name: Supernovae
spaceObjects.description: A supernova is the explosion of a star that briefly outshines an entire galaxy, radiating as much energy as the Sun would emit over its entire life span.
facts: Supernovae are the largest explosions that take place in space.
They can briefly outshine entire galaxies and radiate more energy than our sun will in its entire lifetime.
Supernovae are the primary source of heavy elements in the universe.
There are two main types: Type Ia (white dwarf explosion) and Type II (massive star collapse).
The last supernova observed in our Milky Way was in 1604, known as Kepler's Supernova.
spaceObjects.frequency: 1-2 per century in a typical galaxy
spaceObjects.importance: Create and disperse heavy elements throughout the universe
spaceObjects.famous: SN 1054 (created the Crab Nebula), SN 1987A (closest observed in modern times)

spaceObjects.name: Pulsars
spaceObjects.description: A pulsar is a highly magnetized rotating neutron star that emits beams of electromagnetic radiation out of its magnetic poles.
facts: Pulsars rotate extremely rapidly, with periods from milliseconds to seconds.
They emit regular pulses of radiation that can be detected as radio waves.
Pulsars are formed from the collapsed cores of massive stars after supernova explosions.
The fastest known pulsar rotates about 716 times per second.
Pulsars are used as cosmic clocks due to their extremely precise rotation periods.
spaceObjects.discovery: First discovered by Jocelyn Bell Burnell in 1967
spaceObjects.rotation: From milliseconds to seconds per rotation
spaceObjects.importance: Used for testing theories of gravity and detecting gravitational waves

spaceObjects.name: Quasars
spaceObjects.description: Quasars are extremely luminous active galactic nuclei, powered by supermassive black holes with masses ranging from millions to billions of times that of the Sun.
facts: Quasars are among the brightest objects in the universe.
They are powered by supermassive black holes at the centers of galaxies.
Quasars can emit up to a thousand times the energy output of the entire Milky Way.
Most quasars are billions of light-years away, showing us the universe as it was in the distant past.
The term 'quasar' comes from 'quasi-stellar radio source' as they appeared star-like but emitted radio waves.
spaceObjects.discovery: First identified in the 1950s as radio sources
spaceObjects.distance: Most are billions of light-years from Earth
spaceObjects.power: Generated by matter falling into supermassive black holes
spaceObjects.importance: Help astronomers study the early universe and galaxy evolution

spaceObjects.name: Dark Matter
spaceObjects.description: Dark matter is a hypothetical form of matter thought to account for approximately 85% of the matter in the universe. It has not been directly observed, but its existence is implied by various astrophysical observations.
facts: Dark matter does not interact with the electromagnetic force, making it invisible.
Its existence is inferred from gravitational effects on visible matter and background radiation.
Dark matter is estimated to constitute about 27% of the universe's total mass-energy.
Leading candidates for dark matter include weakly interacting massive particles (WIMPs) and axions.
The distribution of dark matter has played a crucial role in the formation of galaxies.
spaceObjects.detection: Inferred through gravitational effects on visible matter
spaceObjects.composition: Unknown, but theorized to be exotic non-baryonic particles
spaceObjects.distribution: Forms halos around galaxies and extends beyond visible matter
spaceObjects.importance: Essential for understanding galaxy formation and cosmic structure

spaceObjects.name: Exoplanets
spaceObjects.description: Exoplanets are planets outside our solar system that orbit other stars. They come in a wide variety of sizes and compositions, from gas giants to rocky worlds.
facts: Over 5,000 exoplanets have been confirmed as of 2023, with thousands more candidates awaiting confirmation.
The first exoplanet around a Sun-like star was discovered in 1995.
Some exoplanets orbit in the 'habitable zone' where liquid water could exist on their surface.
Exoplanets are detected through various methods, including transit photometry and radial velocity measurements.
The nearest known exoplanet is Proxima Centauri b, about 4.2 light-years from Earth.
spaceObjects.types: Gas Giants, Ice Giants, Super-Earths, Terrestrial, Hot Jupiters
spaceObjects.detection: Transit method, radial velocity, direct imaging, gravitational microlensing
spaceObjects.habitable: Some exist in their star's 'habitable zone' where liquid water could exist
spaceObjects.famous: Proxima Centauri b, TRAPPIST-1 system, HD 209458 b (Osiris)
